pages.title: Forcing Evolution
pages.text: When crossbreeding, crops have a small chance to mutate. Mutations climb a "step-ladder":$(br2)A recessive $(4)'a'$() might mutate into a dominant $(2)'A'$(). A dominant $(2)'A'$() might mutate into the next tier's recessive $(4)'b'$().$(br2)Beware: roughly $(c)15% of mutations are Regressive$(), meaning the gene steps backward!

pages.title: The Modifier Gene
pages.text: The final two letters of the genome (Slots 7 & 8) don't give stats. Instead, they act as the $(d)Modifier Locus$().$(br2)$(li)A dominant purebred modifier (e.g., $(2)SS$()) acts as a $(2)Genetic Lock$(), drastically reducing the chance of mutations.$(li)A recessive purebred modifier (e.g., $(4)ss$()) acts as a $(4)Mutation Engine$(), heavily boosting the chance of genetic drift.
